user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32                             status;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(impl->dl_handle, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl:
extern OS_impl_module_internal_record_t OS_impl_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code uses *token only as an rvalue to index the object table; token is declared const OS_object_token_t * so neither the pointer variable nor the pointed-to object is being modified in this fragment. There is no assignment to token and nothing in the shown code mutates *token, so Rule 17.8 (do not modify function parameters or the pointer itself) is not violated.
